DOCNAME: CASE OF FAYED v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
CONCLUSION: Preliminary objection rejected (non-exhaustion);No violation of Art. 6-1;Not necessary to examine Art. 13
TEXT: CARDINAL . ORG The CARDINAL applicants , Mr PERSON , Mr PERSON and Mr PERSON , are brothers . They are businessmen .

CARDINAL . ORG In DATE the applicants acquired ownership of the ORG of ORG ( " ORG " ) , a public company , for MONEY in cash . ORG was then , and is now , one of the largest groups of department stores in LOC and includes one particularly well - known GPE store , ORG . The acquisition of ORG was effected through a public company called ORG of ORG ( " ORG " ) , which at all material times was owned by the applicants . ORG had previously been known as ORG ( GPE ) ORG and assumed its present name in DATE .

CARDINAL . ORG Prior to the ORG takeover , in or DATE , the applicants appointed public relations consultants . With the latter ’s assistance , the brothers and their direct advisers led the press to receive and present a positive picture of their origins , wealth , business interests and resources . Upon the basis of this picture , which they had a part in painting , they enjoyed , for a time , an esteem or reputation which was highly valuable to them . CARDINAL applicant gave separate interviews to ORG , The DATE FAC and ORG . A further interview involving the brothers took place on DATE . In these interviews the brothers described a wealthy , distinguished and established family background . They gave a similar picture to their merchant banker , who accepted it and , acting on their behalf , conveyed that picture by a press release in DATE and in a television interview in DATE . There were other press interviews about the family background for which the applicants were responsible .

They thus took active steps to promote their own reputations in the public domain . The acceptance of the brothers by GPE and by the Government was later considered to be crucial to an understanding of the events surrounding their takeover of ORG .

CARDINAL . ORG The takeover was vigorously but unsuccessfully opposed by ORG ( " Lonrho " ) and , in particular , its Chief Executive , PERSON , a former business associate , turned rival , of the applicants .

From DATE , if not earlier , it had been ORG ’s wish to acquire ORG . In DATE , following a report from ORG the Secretary of ORG ( " the Secretary of ORG " ) had sought and obtained from ORG undertakings not to acquire or control any further shareholdings beyond its then level of PERCENT of ORG . Thereafter ORG had sought to be released from these undertakings .

In DATE ORG had sold its share - holding in GPE to the applicants , but when those directors representing ORG ’s interests were obliged to resign from ORG and the applicants bid to take over ORG completely , relations between PERSON and the applicants deteriorated . PERSON proceeded to launch an acrimonious campaign against the applicants . In opposing the applicants’ bid for ORG , ORG had made submissions to Ministers concerning unfair competition and the undesirability of ORG falling into foreign hands . It was alleged that the applicants were fraudulently claiming that the funds for the acquisition were theirs personally . PERSON asserted that the brothers were lying about their money and themselves and that they should not be permitted to acquire ORG without a thorough inquiry . However , the ORG bid was cleared by ORG ( " ORG " ) and accepted by ORG . In DATE the Secretary of ORG decided , on the recommendation of ORG , not to refer the ORG proposed acquisition to ORG , as had been done in the case of the earlier bid by ORG . The decision of Government clearance was expressly described at the time by the ORG as having been influenced by the statements made and assurances given by and on behalf of the PERSON brothers about their bid . ORG nevertheless campaigned on through the media and other publications , and in particular through The ORG , a newspaper it owned .

CARDINAL . ORG The applicants instructed their solicitors to threaten and , if necessary , institute libel proceedings if anything were published putting in doubt their claim to be the beneficial owners of the funds used to acquire ORG . This policy affected several publications , including ORG . In almost every instance the threat of action led to the publication of a retraction . The applicants instituted CARDINAL libel actions against ORG in DATE and DATE for articles written about them . CARDINAL central issue in these actions was the truth or not of The ORG ’s allegation that the funds used by the applicants in their takeover of ORG were not their own .

CARDINAL . ORG In DATE ORG commenced legal proceedings against the applicants and their bankers alleging wrongful interference with ORG ’s business , and conspiracy and negligence in connection with ORG ’s acquisition of ORG . In particular , it was alleged that the applicants , by false statements about their financial capacity to acquire the share capital and develop ORG ’s business , had persuaded ORG to accept their bid and had convinced the Secretary of ORG not to refer their bid to ORG . It was claimed that the applicants had thereby tortiously interfered with ORG ’s right to bid for the shares or , alternatively , they had conspired against ORG .
ORG unsuccessfully sought leave to apply for judicial review of the Secretary of ORG ’s refusal to refer the applicants’ acquisition of ORG to ORG .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE , after DATE of unrelenting pressure by ORG upon the ORG , the Secretary of ORG appointed CARDINAL ORG to investigate the affairs of ORG and , in particular , the circumstances surrounding the acquisition of shares in ORG in DATE and DATE . The appointment of the ORG was made by the Secretary of ORG under section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of LAW DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . They were told at the time of their appointment , and they so informed the applicants , that an area of particular concern to the Secretary of ORG was the validity of the assurances given by the applicants and their advisers in DATE ( Inspectors’ report , paragraphs PERSON , ORG and CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . ORG In their subsequent report the ORG described the ORG takeover bid as being unusual , not least because it was a bid involving huge sums of money by CARDINAL individuals and , since the offerers were individuals , the corporate balance sheets and other financial statements which are customary on such occasions were totally absent ( Inspectors’ report , paragraph CARDINAL ) . In order to establish what had occurred during the takeover , they had been obliged to make findings on vigorously contested issues of fact ( Inspectors’ report , paragraph CARDINAL ) .
The principal questions they addressed when investigating the affairs of ORG were listed in their report as follows :
" ( i ) ORG Were the PERSON who they said they were , and if not who were they ?
( ii ) ORG Did they acquire ORG with their own unencumbered funds ?

( iv ) ORG If so , did they seek to frustrate those who tried to establish the true facts , and if so how ?

( The Inspectors’ report , paragraph CARDINAL )

The ORG also stated that , throughout their investigation , they were not concerned solely with simple questions relating to the direct control of the purchase money which was used to buy ORG . They were also concerned about the veracity of the statements which the applicants made , or which they allowed others to make on their behalf , which had the effect of influencing people to act favourably towards them ( Inspectors’ report , paragraph CARDINAL ; and also chapter CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . ORG During the course of the investigation , the ORG identified matters upon which they wished to receive evidence . If any uncertainty or issue arose in relation to the provision of such evidence , these were discussed in the course of meetings or through correspondence between the Inspectors’ staff and the applicants’ solicitors . Thereafter , information was provided to the ORG by way of memoranda , together with copy documentation . In addition , the ORG received oral evidence by interviewing witnesses on oath . Mr PERSON and Mr PERSON were interviewed , in the presence of their lawyers , on DATE and again on DATE . All proceedings were conducted in private . There was no opportunity for the applicants to confront or cross - examine witnesses , it being well - established as a matter of LANGUAGE law that the Inspectors were not obliged to afford such an opportunity to anyone .

CARDINAL . ORG It was agreed between the ORG and the applicants that , having assimilated the factual information supplied , the ORG would notify the applicants of the provisional conclusions they had reached and the material upon which they had relied in reaching such conclusions . The ORG would then consider such submissions as the applicants might make in respect of these conclusions .

CARDINAL . Respect for personal privacy was known to be a matter of especial concern to the applicants . The Inspectors’ approach to matters of privacy and confidentiality is summed up in their report ( at paragraphs CARDINAL - CARDINAL ) as follows :

" [ I]f private people incorporate a company , in which they become directors , and which makes public representations about their affairs , ORG who are appointed to investigate the truth of those representations must balance their concern to preserve the ORG privacy as far as practicable ... against their duty to do the job which they were appointed to perform .

If the PERSON had chosen to say nothing this might have created evidential difficulties for us . But because they wished us to make findings in their favour they brought witnesses to see us ... and gave us evidence about their private affairs which it was then our duty to test . "

CARDINAL . ORG At the start of the investigation the applicants expressly accepted that the Inspectors were entitled to inquire into the accuracy of statements which had been made by them or on their behalf in DATE and DATE . These were the statements at the heart of the investigation . Only at DATE of the investigation , when they were confronted by the ORG with " overwhelming evidence " that they had been telling lies , did they resile from that stance and challenge the Inspectors’ entitlement to look into certain aspects of their private life ( Inspectors’ report , paragraph CARDINAL ) .

The ORG rejected the challenge and gave their reasons for so doing ( see generally chapter CARDINAL of the Inspectors’ report ) . The ORG were entitled to seek confidential information from third parties , but before doing so they gave the applicants an opportunity to satisfy them as to the accuracy of the statements " in whatever manner was least obtrusive to their privacy " ( Inspectors’ report , paragraphs DATE and CARDINAL ) . The law did not permit them to compel the applicants to produce personal bank statements ( which would have gone far to confirm or refute the accuracy of the statements ) nor , save to a very limited extent , did the applicants consent to such production . The ORG considered that the applicants were in breach of their duty to give all the assistance which they were reasonably required to give . By virtue of section CARDINAL of the DATE LAW could have certified this to a court , which could then have taken steps to sanction the applicants if , after hearing evidence , it was satisfied that they were in breach of their duty ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . The ORG were , however , of the opinion that they could complete their task without the need to resort to such a serious measure and chose to pursue the matter without making such a certificate . They made clear that if the applicants chose not to give evidence , they , the ORG , would be entitled to draw inferences from such failure .

DATE and DATE there was no significant response from the applicants . CARDINAL . ORG The ORG concluded that the applicants had dishonestly misrepresented their origins , their wealth , their business interests and their resources to the Secretary of ORG , ORG , the press , ORG and ORG shareholders and their own advisers ; that during the course of their investigations , the ORG had received evidence from the applicants , under solemn affirmation and in written memoranda , which was false and which the applicants knew to be false ; in addition , that the applicants had produced a set of documents they knew to be false ; that this evidence related mainly , but not exclusively , to their background , their past business activities and the way in which they came to be in control of enormous funds in DATE and DATE ( see especially Inspectors’ report , chapter CARDINAL ) . CARDINAL . ORG The investigation of ORG was conducted under section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of LAW DATE in relation to the circumstances surrounding the acquisition of shares in ORG in DATE and DATE . LAW ( CARDINAL ) empowers the Secretary of ORG to appoint ORG to investigate the affairs of a company and to report on them in such manner as he directs if it appears to him that there are circumstances suggesting wrongdoing , within the categories of wrongdoing defined as follows :

" ( a ) that the company ’s affairs are being or have been conducted with intent to defraud its creditors or the creditors of any other person , or otherwise for a fraudulent or unlawful purpose , or in a manner which is unfairly prejudicial to some part of its members , or

( b ) ORG that any actual or proposed act or omission of the company ( including an act or omission on its behalf ) is or would be so prejudicial , or that the company was formed for any fraudulent or unlawful purpose , or

( c ) ORG that persons concerned with the company ’s formation or the management of its affairs have in connection therewith been guilty of fraud , misfeasance or other misconduct towards it or towards its members , or
( d ) ORG that the company ’s members have not been given all the information with respect to its affairs which they might reasonably expect . "

CARDINAL . ORG The Secretary of ORG is under no statutory obligation to disclose to the company concerned the reasons for the appointment of ORG to investigate its affairs ( ORG v. Secretary of ORG [ DATE ] CARDINAL Weekly Law Reports CARDINAL ( ORG ) ) ; nor does he generally do so . In the present case , when requested by ORG to do so in the course of ORG ’s judicial review applications , counsel for the ORG stated that the Secretary of ORG had acted under section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ( a ) in appointing the ORG .

CARDINAL . ORG Section CARDINAL confers wide powers upon the ORG to obtain information , if necessary by compulsion , from officers and agents of the company whose affairs are being investigated . An answer given by a person to a question put to him in exercise of powers conferred by section CARDINAL may be used in evidence against him ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ) . Under section CARDINAL obstruction of the ORG may be certified by them to a court , which may , after enquiry , treat it as a contempt of court punishable by imprisonment or fine .

CARDINAL . ORG The ORG are bound by the rules of natural justice ; they have a duty to act fairly and to give anyone whom they propose to criticise in their report a fair opportunity to answer what is alleged against them ( In re ORG [ DATE ] CARDINAL Chancery CARDINAL ( ORG ) ) . The ORG in the present case accepted as applicable to them the principle of natural justice whereby a person exercising an investigatory jurisdiction must base his or her findings on material having probative value ( Inspectors’ report , paragraphs CARDINAL and CARDINAL - citing ORG v. Air GPE [ DATE ] Appeal Cases CARDINAL ( ORG ) , at pp . CARDINAL - CARDINAL ) .

However , proceedings before the ORG are administrative in form , not judicial ; the ORG are not a court of law and they are masters of their own procedure ( In re ORG , loc . cit . , pp . CARDINAL , per Lord ORG ; pp . CARDINAL - CARDINAL , per PERSON ) . Except for the duty to act fairly , Inspectors are not subject to any set rules or procedures and are free to act at their own discretion . There is no right for a person who is at risk of being criticised by the ORG to cross - examine witnesses ( ibid . , p. CARDINAL , per Lord PERSON ) . It is not necessary for the ORG to put their tentative conclusions to the witnesses in order to give them a chance to refute them . It is sufficient in law for the ORG to put to the witnesses what has been said against them by other persons or in documents to enable them to deal with those criticisms in the course of the investigation ( ORG [ DATE ] CARDINAL Queen ’s Bench CARDINAL ( ORG ) ) .

CARDINAL . ORG The Secretary of ORG is empowered by section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ( c ) to decide whether or not to print and publish the Inspectors’ report . Although he has a very wide discretion in deciding whether or not to publish the whole report , he is precluded by section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ( c ) from deciding to publish only parts or a synopsis of it .
Publication may be deferred if there is a possibility that criminal proceedings may be taken , in order to avoid the possibility of prejudice to such proceedings .

CARDINAL . ORG The question whether an ORG ’s report should be published is considered in each case on its merits . The ORG ’s general policy is to publish reports on public companies wherever possible , as being matters of public interest .

Members of a limited company are in a privileged legal position because their liability is limited . In view of this privilege , where the Secretary of ORG has decided that the affairs of a large public company should be investigated under the provisions of section CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act , because he is satisfied that the circumstances are of sufficient concern to warrant the substantial cost of an inspection , it is important that the Inspectors’ report explaining the underlying facts and the conclusions that they draw from them should be made public unless there are overriding reasons to the contrary .

CARDINAL . ORG The defence of privilege or immunity in defamation cases rests upon the idea that conduct which would otherwise be actionable escapes liability because the defendant is acting in furtherance of some interest of social importance which is entitled to protection , even at the expense of uncompensated harm to the plaintiff ’s reputation . If the interest is CARDINAL of paramount importance , considerations of policy may require that the defendant ’s immunity for false statements be absolute , without regard to his purpose or motive or the reasonableness of his conduct . Such is the nature of the absolute protection afforded to judicial and parliamentary proceedings . Also on grounds of public policy , a defence of qualified privilege may lie when the publication is made by a person in good faith and in the discharge of some public or private duty . The condition attached to qualified privilege is that it must be exercised in a reasonable manner and for a proper purpose . A publisher with malicious intent would lose the defence of qualified privilege .
CARDINAL . ORG In re ORG ( loc . cit . , at p. CARDINAL G ) Lord PERSON stated :

" Inspectors should make their report with courage and frankness , keeping nothing back . The public interest demands it . They need have no fear because their report , so far as I can judge , is protected by an absolute privilege ... "

Even if , contrary to Lord PERSON ’s observation , the Inspectors’ report is subject to a qualified rather than an absolute privilege , neither the ORG nor the Secretary of ORG could be successfully sued for defamation in publishing the report , except upon proof of express malice ( that is , the desire to injure as the dominant motive for the defamatory publication : see PERSON v. PERSON [ DATE ] Appeal Cases CARDINAL ( ORG ) , at p. CARDINAL , per Lord PERSON ) .

CARDINAL . ORG The grounds on which administrative action ( such as the Secretary of ORG ’s decision to publish the report ) is subject to judicial control are the CARDINAL traditional grounds of judicial review described by Lord PERSON in ORG Unions v. Minister for ORG ( [ DATE ] Appeal Cases CARDINAL ( ORG ) , at pp . CARDINAL - CARDINAL ) . These grounds are illegality , irrationality and procedural impropriety .
" Illegality " means that the decision - maker must understand correctly the law that regulates his decision - making power and must give effect to it .

" Irrationality " , or what is often also referred to as " ORG unreasonableness " ( see ORG v. ORG [ DATE ] CARDINAL King ’s Bench CARDINAL ( ORG ) ) , applies to a decision which is so outrageous in its defiance of logic or of accepted moral standards that no sensible person who had applied his mind to the question to be decided could have arrived at it . " ‘ ORG or ORG is a narrowly restricted ground of judicial review of an administrative decision . Where the existence or non - existence of a fact is left to the judgment and discretion of a public body and that fact involves a broad spectrum ranging from the obvious to the debatable to the just conceivable , it is the duty of the court to leave the decision of fact to the public body to whom ORG has entrusted the decision - making power save in a case where it is obvious that the public body , consciously or unconsciously , are acting perversely " ( per Lord PERSON , in NORP v. PERSON , ex parte ORG [ DATE ] Appeal Cases CARDINAL ( ORG ) , p. CARDINAL ) .

" Procedural impropriety " covers failure to observe basic rules of natural justice or failure to act with procedural fairness towards the person who will be affected by the decision , as well as failure to observe procedural rules that are expressly laid down even where such failure does not involve any denial of natural justice .

CARDINAL . ORG Judicial review would , for example , provide a remedy if Inspectors under LAW were prejudiced or biased against the subjects of their report ( ORG v. Minister of ORG [ DATE ] Appeal Cases CARDINAL ( ORG ) ) ; or if the ORG reached conclusions which there were no facts to support , or took into account irrelevant considerations , or failed to take account of relevant considerations , or reached conclusions which no reasonable person in their position could have reached ( the PERSON case , loc . cit . ) ; or if their findings have not been properly based on material which has probative value ( PERSON v. Air GPE , loc . cit . ) ; or if the ORG were dishonest or acted in bad faith ( the ORG case , loc . cit . ) ; or if the ORG acted ultra vires or beyond their legal powers ( the PERSON case , loc . cit . ) ; or if the ORG acted against the legitimate expectations of those concerned ( ORG Unions v. Minister for ORG , loc . cit . ) ; or if the ORG acted contrary to the rules of natural justice ( PERSON v. PERSON [ DATE ] Appeal Cases CARDINAL ( ORG ) ) ; or if the ORG acted unfairly ( In re ORG , loc . cit . ; ORG , loc . cit . ; NORP v. Panel on ORG , ex parte ORG [ DATE ] CARDINAL Queen ’s Bench CARDINAL ( ORG ) ) .

However , a mistake of fact could not form the basis of a challenge to an administrative decision by the ORG or the Secretary of ORG unless the fact was a condition precedent to an exercise of jurisdiction , or the fact was the only evidential basis for a decision , or the fact was as to a matter which expressly or impliedly had to be taken into account ( NORP v. ORG , ex parte ORG , ORG , DATE ( ORG ) ) .
